heading: Dit313 Calculationability, 7.5 higher education credits
content:
Computability, 7.5 Credits

Advanced Level / Second Cycle

heading: Determination
content:
The syllabus is established by the Department of Computer and Information Technology 2021-11-15 to apply from 2022-08-29, autumn term 2022.

Area of Education: Natural Science 100 % Responsible Institutions: Department of Computer and Information Technology

heading: Placement
content:
The course is offered within several educational programs.It is also given as a standalone course at the University of Gothenburg.

The course may be included in the following programs: 1) Computer Science Program (N1COS) and 2) Computer Science, Master's Program (N2COS)

Main area

Recess

Computer science

A1n, Advanced Level, has only course/ER at basic level as prerequisites

heading: Prerequisites
content:
For access to the course, the student must have at least 120 credits in computer science or equivalent.Specifically, the following courses, or equivalent: - 7.5 credits in discrete mathematics (eg, 1980 Discrete mathematics for computer scientists) - 7.5 credits in functional programming (eg, 143 Functional programming or DR) introduction to functional programming)

The following level of knowledge in English is required;English 6/English B or equivalent from a recognized international test, e.g.Toefl, IELTS.

heading: Learning goals
content: After approved course, the student should be able to:

heading: Knowledge and understanding
content:
- define the concept of computable function,
- Explain Church-TURINGS hypothesis,
- Explain the relationship between inductively defined quantities, primitive recursion, and the method of evidence structural induction,

heading: Skills and ability
content:
- prove that quantities are insistent or in -house, for example by using diagonalization,
- Code inductively defined quantities in such a way that elements in these quantities can be used as input or output for programs in one or more calculation models,
- implement programs, in particular interpreters, correctly in one or more calculation models,
- Prove that features are or are not computable in any calculation models,

heading: Valuation and attitude
content:
- Analyze programs belong to some calculation models, and
- Manipulate and analyze calculation models.

heading: Content
content:
The course is about calculations: how they can be modeled, and what can be calculated.To avoid unnecessary complications, one often chooses to study calculations through simplified, but powerful, models.For example, these models can be simple programming languages (such as -calculation), or idealized computers (as Turing machines).The course deals with several such models, both "imperative" and "functional".

One or more models will be used to explore the limits of what can be calculated: problems that cannot be solved (within a particular model framework), and programs that can run arbitrary programs (modeled in a certain way).

The course also contains a discussion of Church-TURING's hypothesis, a presumption that a function is computable in a certain intuitive way only if it can be defined in one of several calculation models.

heading: Sub -courses
content:
1. Written exam (Written Examination), 4.5 credits rating scale: very well approved (5), well approved (4), approved (3) and

Rating scale: very well approved (5), well approved (4), approved (3) and

Failed (u)

- 2.

- submission tasks (assignments), 3 credits

Rating scale: approved (g) and failed (u)

heading: Forms of teaching
content:
Lectures and exercises.

Language Language: English

heading: Forms of assessment
content:
The course is examined through an individual written examination and individual assignments.

If a student who has been rejected twice at the same examination element wishes to change the examiner for the next examination occasion, such a request must be submitted in writing to the course responsible institution and approved if there are no special reasons, however (HF Chapter 6, section 22).

In the event that a course has ceased or undergone major changes, the student must normally be guaranteed access to at least three test cases (including regular test occasions) for a period of at least one year based on the course's previous arrangement.

heading: Rating
content:
The course gives any of the grades very well approved (5), well approved (4), approved (3) and failed (U).

To get one of the grades 5, 4 or 3, you must receive the grade G on the sub -course assignments, and partly that you get approved results (5, 4 or 3) on the sub -course written hall.In that case, the grade on the entire course is the grade on the sub -course written hall exam.Otherwise, the grade on the entire course is U (failed).

heading: Course evaluation
content:
The course is evaluated through meetings both during and after the course between teachers and student representatives.In addition, an anonymous questionnaire is used to receive written information.The result of the evaluation is used to improve the course by the fact that

Show on parts that can be added, improved, changed or removed.

heading: Other
content:
The course is collected with Chalmers.

Course literature will be published no later than 8 weeks before the course starts.

The course replaces the course Dit312, 7.5 credits.This course cannot be included in a degree containing there312.Nor can it be part of a degree based on another degree that includes 312.

heading: Dit231 Program language technology, 7.5 higher education credits
content:
Programming Language Technology, 7.5 Credits

Advanced Level / Second Cycle

heading: Determination
content:
The syllabus is established by the Department of Computer and Information Technology 2012-11-12 and last revised 2019-02-07.The revised syllabus is valid from 201909-02, autumn term 2019.

Area of Education: Natural Science 100 %

Responsible institution: Department of Computer and Information Technology

heading: Placement
content:
The course is part of Computer Science Master's program and is given as a standalone course at the University of Gothenburg.

The course may be included in the following programs: 1) Computer science program (N1COS), 2) Computer Science, Master's Program (N2COS), 3) Software Engineering Master's Program (N2Som) and 4) Applied Data Science Master Program (N2ADS)

Main area

heading: Recess
content:
Software Engineering

A1n, Advanced Level, has only course/ER at basic level as prerequisites

Computer Science-Algorithms and Logic

A1n, Advanced Level, has only course/ER at basic level as prerequisites

heading: Prerequisites
content:
Prerequisites for the course are completed courses of 60 credits in the subject of computer science including:

- 7.5 credits Programming (for example, DR) Functional Programming, DRA953 Object -oriented Programming and Design or equivalent)
- 7.5 credits Data structures (for example DR there961 Data structures, DRA 725 Logic, algorithms and data structures or equivalent)

English 6/English B or present the corresponding level of knowledge through an internationally recognized language test such as Toefl, IELTS.

heading: Learning goals
content: After completing the course, the student should be able to:

heading: Knowledge and understanding
content:
- Explain basic implementation problems for both imperative and functional languages,
- Explain the principles of LL and LR pairs,
- Explain how finite vending machines work,

heading: Skills and ability
content:
- Define and implement abstract syntax,
- Define Syntax for Programming Languages using context -free grammar and implement parsers using standard tools,
- Design rules for operational semantics and implement interpreters for both imperative and functional languages,
- Write simple code generators,
- Apply the technology for syntax -controlled translation and how to implement for any programming language,
- Formulate typeinference rules and implement type controllers for functional and imperative programming languages,
- Design rules for operational semantic and implement interpreters for functional and imperative programming languages,

heading: Valuation and attitude
content: - reason about programming language design and make balances, for example, with regard to efficiency and usability.

heading: Content
content:
The purpose of the course is to create an understanding of how programming languages are designed, documented and implemented.The course deals with basic techniques and tools needed to implement interpreters (interpreters), and also provides an introduction to compilers.

Students will learn the program language grammar when they implement syntax analysis and about type system when implementing type controllers.By implementing interpreters and compilers, the student learns to solve practical implementation problems as well as the theory for formal semantics.

heading: Sub -courses
content:
1. The exam (Written Exam), 6 credits

- rating scale: well approved (VG), approved (g) and failed (U)

2. Laborations (Laboratory), 1.5 credits

Rating scale: approved (g) and failed (u)

heading: Forms of teaching
content:
Teaching is given in the form of lectures, exercises and laboratory work with individual guidance.

Language Language:

English

heading: Forms of assessment
content:
The course is examined through an individual written examination at the end of the course and laboratory work that is carried out individually or in pairs.

If a student who has been rejected twice at the same examination element wishes to change the examiner for the next examination occasion, such a request must be submitted in writing to the course responsible institution and approved if there are no special reasons, however (HF Chapter 6, section 22).

In the event that a course has ceased or undergone major changes, the student must normally be guaranteed access to at least three test cases (including regular test occasions) for a period of at least one year based on the course's previous arrangement.

heading: Rating
content: The course gives any of the grades well approved (VG), approved (G) and failed (U).In order to obtain a well -approved (VG) for the entire course, the student must be approved at the part of the laboratory work and received the grade well approved at the sub -written exam.

heading: Course evaluation
content: The course is evaluated through meetings both during and after the course between teachers and student representatives.In addition, an anonymous questionnaire is used to receive written information.The result of the evaluation is used to improve the course by showing parts that can be added, improved, changed or removed.

heading: Other
content:
The course replaces DRA230 Programming Languages.The course cannot be included in a degree containing there 230.Nor can the course be included in a degree based on another degree where 230 is included.

The course cannot be included in a degree containing there229.Nor can the course be included in a degree based on another degree which includes the course DR229.

The course is collected with Chalmers.

Course Literature to Be Announced The Latest 8 Weeks Prior to the Start of the Course.
